modules.policy package¶

Submodules¶

modules.policy.evaluation module¶

class ObjectiveReachedEvaluator(domain: utils.domain.domain.Domain, turn_reward=-1, success_reward=20, logger: utils.logger.DiasysLogger = <DiasysLogger adviser (NOTSET)>)[source]¶

Bases: object

Evaluate single turns and complete dialog.

This class assigns a negative reward to each turn. In case the user’s goal could be satisfied (meaning a matching database entry was found), a large final reward is returned.

Only needed when training against a simulator.

get_final_reward(sim_goal: utils.goal.Goal, logging=True)[source]¶

Check whether the user’s goal was completed.

Returns

Reward - the final reward (0 (unsuccessful) or 20 (successful)) Success - True or false

Bases: modules.module.Module

Policy evaluation module

Plug this module into the dialog graph (somewhere after the policy), and policy metrics like success rate and reward will be recorded.

modules.policy.policy_handcrafted module¶

class HandcraftedPolicy(domain: utils.domain.jsonlookupdomain.JSONLookupDomain, subgraph=None, logger: utils.logger.DiasysLogger = <DiasysLogger adviser (NOTSET)>)[source]¶

Bases: modules.module.Module

Base class for handcrafted policies.

Provides a simple rule-based policy. Can be used for any domain where a user is trying to find an entity (eg. a course from a module handbook) from a database by providing constraints (eg. semester the course is offered) or where a user is trying to find out additional information about a named entity.

Output is a system action such as:

  • inform – provides information on an entity

  • request – request more information from the user

  • bye – issue parting message and end dialog

In order to create your own policy, you can inherit from this class. Make sure to overwrite the forward-method with whatever additionally rules/functionality required.

forward(dialog_graph, beliefstate: utils.beliefstate.BeliefState = None, user_acts: List[utils.useract.UserAct] = None, sys_act: utils.sysact.SysAct = None, **kwargs) → {'sys_act': <class 'utils.sysact.SysAct'>}[source]¶

Responsible for walking the policy through a single turn. Uses the current user action and system belief state to determine what the next system action should be.

To implement an alternate policy, this method may need to be overwritten

Parameters

  • dialog_graph (DialogSystem) – the graph to which the policy belongs

  • belief_state (BeliefState) – a BeliefState obejct representing current system knowledge

  • user_acts (list) – a list of UserAct objects mapped from the user’s last utterance

  • sys_act (SysAct) – this should be None

Returns

a dictionary with the key “sys_act” and the value that of the systems next

action

Return type

(dict)

modules.policy.policy_rl module¶

class RLPolicy(domain: utils.domain.jsonlookupdomain.JSONLookupDomain, subgraph=None, buffer_cls=<class 'modules.policy.rl.experience_buffer.UniformBuffer'>, buffer_size=6000, batch_size=64, discount_gamma=0.99, include_confreq=False, logger: utils.logger.DiasysLogger = <DiasysLogger adviser (NOTSET)>)[source]¶

Bases: modules.module.Module

Base class for Reinforcement Learning based policies.

Functionality provided includes the setup of state- and action spaces, conversion of BeliefState objects into pytorch tensors, updating the last performed system actions and informed entities, populating the experience replay buffer, extraction of most probable user hypothesis and candidate action expansion.

Output of an agent is a candidate action like inform_food which is then populated with the most probable slot/value pair from the beliefstate and database candidates by the expand_system_action-function to become inform(slot=food,value=italian).

In order to create your own policy, you can inherit from this class. Make sure to call the turn_end-function after each system turn and the end_dialog-function after each completed dialog and to overwrite the forward-method.
